title: Different ways of knowing - Daniel Tammet

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition that the speaker has, which allows them to see words, numbers, and colors in a unique way?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the counsellor's solution to the king's problem?

options.label: A
options.text: Keep the triangle and give the two small squares to one daughter and the largest square to the other.

options.label: B
options.text: Give the triangle to one daughter and the two small squares to the other.

options.label: C
options.text: Keep the triangle and give the largest blob to one daughter and the two small blobs to the other.

options.label: D
options.text: Give the triangle to one daughter and the largest blob to the other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the counsellor's key insight about similar figures?

options.label: A
options.text: If the lengths of the figures are doubled, the areas are multiplied by 4.

options.label: B
options.text: If the lengths of the figures are tripled, the areas are multiplied by 9.

options.label: C
options.text: If the lengths of the figures are scaled by some factor, the areas are scaled by the square of that factor.

options.label: D
options.text: If the lengths of the figures are scaled by some factor, the areas are scaled by that factor.

multiple-choice.question: What is the counsellor's definition of the "blob Pythagorean theorem"?

options.label: A
options.text: A theorem that states that the area of a triangle is equal to half the product of its base and height.

options.label: B
options.text: A theorem that states that the sum of the areas of two smaller blobs is equal to the area of a larger blob.

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that states that for any blob, the area of a larger blob is equal to the sum of the areas of two smaller blobs similar to it.

options.label: D
options.text: A theorem that states that for any blob, the area of a larger blob is equal to the product of the areas of two smaller blobs similar to it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the counsellor's solution to the king's request to see the blob Pythagorean theorem in action?

options.label: A
options.text: He draws a single line that meets the large side in a right angle.

options.label: B
options.text: He draws a triangle with one side equal to the length of the blob.

options.label: C
options.text: He draws a triangle with two sides equal to the lengths of the blobs.

options.label: D
options.text: He draws a triangle with one side equal to the length of the largest blob and two sides equal to the lengths of the smaller blobs.

title: Not all scientific studies are created equal - David H. Schwartz

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific gold standard for studying the effects of a new medication or treatment on humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Randomized clinical trial (RCT)

options.label: B
options.text: Epidemiological study

options.label: C
options.text: Animal study

options.label: D
options.text: Cell study

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to conduct a randomized clinical trial in many cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it requires too many volunteers

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is not practical

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is too expensive

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is too time-consuming

multiple-choice.question: What is a cohort in an epidemiological study?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of people who are randomly assigned to receive a new medication

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people who already take a particular ingredient in their everyday lives

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who do not have exposure to a particular ingredient

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who are randomly assigned to receive a placebo

multiple-choice.question: What are confounding variables in an epidemiological study?

options.label: A
options.text: Factors that can affect results in addition to the factor being studied

options.label: B
options.text: Factors that can cause a study to be unreliable

options.label: C
options.text: Factors that can affect the outcome of a study

options.label: D
options.text: Factors that can affect the interpretation of a study

multiple-choice.question: What can epidemiological studies demonstrate, but not necessarily prove?

options.label: A
options.text: A true cause and effect relationship between a substance and a health outcome

options.label: B
options.text: A correlation between a substance and a health outcome

options.label: C
options.text: A causal relationship between a substance and a health outcome

options.label: D
options.text: A direct relationship between a substance and a health outcome

options.label: B
options.text: The Theory of Quantum Mechanics

options.label: C
options.text: The Theory of Gravity

options.label: D

options.text: Quantum Superposition Device

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum Chip

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum Leap

options.label: D

options.text: Quantum Superposition

options.text: Quantum Entanglement

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum Fluctuation

options.label: D

options.label: D
